an7.55:1.1.pli: “Satta ca, bhikkhave, purisagatiyo desessāmi anupādā ca parinibbānaṃ.
an7.55:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you seven places people are reborn, and extinguishment by not grasping.

an7.55:1.2.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
an7.55:1.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an7.55:1.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

an7.55:1.5.eng: “And what are the seven places people are reborn?

an7.55:2.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ paṭipanno hoti:
an7.55:2.1.eng: Take a mendicant who practices like this:

an7.55:2.2.pli: ‘no cassa no ca me siyā, na bhavissati na me bhavissati, yadatthi yaṃ bhūtaṃ taṃ pajahāmī’ti upekkhaṃ paṭilabhati.
an7.55:2.2.eng: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’ They gain equanimity.

an7.55:2.3.pli: So bhave na rajjati, sambhave na rajjati, atthuttari padaṃ santaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
an7.55:2.3.eng: They’re not attached to life, or to creating a new life. And they see with right wisdom that there is a peaceful state beyond.

an7.55:2.4.pli: Tañca khvassa padaṃ na sabbena sabbaṃ sacchikataṃ hoti, tassa na sabbena sabbaṃ mānānusayo pahīno hoti, na sabbena sabbaṃ bhavarāgānusayo pahīno hoti, na sabbena sabbaṃ avijjānusayo pahīno hoti.
an7.55:2.4.eng: But they haven’t completely realized that state. They haven’t totally given up the underlying tendencies of conceit, desire for continued existence, and ignorance.

an7.55:2.5.pli: So pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā antarāparinibbāyī hoti.
an7.55:2.5.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished between one life and the next.

an7.55:2.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, divasaṃsantatte ayokapāle haññamāne papaṭikā nibbattitvā nibbāyeyya.
an7.55:2.6.eng: Suppose you struck an iron pot that had been heated all day. Any spark that flew off would be extinguished.

an7.55:2.7.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ paṭipanno hoti:
an7.55:2.7.eng: In the same way, a mendicant who practices like this …

an7.55:2.8.pli: ‘no cassa no ca me siyā, na bhavissati na me bhavissati, yadatthi yaṃ bhūtaṃ taṃ pajahāmī’ti upekkhaṃ paṭilabhati.

an7.55:2.9.pli: So bhave na rajjati, sambhave na rajjati, atthuttari padaṃ santaṃ sammappaññāya passati.

an7.55:2.10.pli: Tañca khvassa padaṃ na sabbena sabbaṃ sacchikataṃ hoti, tassa na sabbena sabbaṃ mānānusayo pahīno hoti, na sabbena sabbaṃ bhavarāgānusayo pahīno hoti, na sabbena sabbaṃ avijjānusayo pahīno hoti.

an7.55:2.11.pli: So pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā antarāparinibbāyī hoti.
an7.55:2.11.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished between one life and the next.

an7.55:4.4.eng: Suppose you struck an iron pot that had been heated all day. Any spark that flew off and floated away would be extinguished before landing.

an7.55:5.4.eng: Suppose you struck an iron pot that had been heated all day. Any spark that flew off and floated away would be extinguished upon landing.

an7.55:5.5.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ paṭipanno hoti:
an7.55:5.5.eng: In the same way, a mendicant who practices like this …

an7.55:5.6.eng: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. …’

an7.55:6.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ paṭipanno hoti:
an7.55:6.1.eng: Take a mendicant who practices like this:

an7.55:6.2.eng: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. …’

an7.55:6.3.pli: so pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an7.55:6.3.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished without extra effort.

an7.55:6.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, divasaṃsantatte ayokapāle haññamāne papaṭikā nibbattitvā uppatitvā paritte tiṇapuñje vā kaṭṭhapuñje vā nipateyya.
an7.55:6.4.eng: Suppose you struck an iron pot that had been heated all day. Any spark that flew off and floated away would fall on a little heap of grass or twigs.

an7.55:6.5.pli: Sā tattha aggimpi janeyya, dhūmampi janeyya, aggimpi janetvā dhūmampi janetvā tameva parittaṃ tiṇapuñjaṃ vā kaṭṭhapuñjaṃ vā pariyādiyitvā anāhārā nibbāyeyya.
an7.55:6.5.eng: There it would ignite a fire and produce smoke. But the fire would consume the grass or twigs and become extinguished due to not being fed.

an7.55:6.6.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ paṭipanno hoti:
an7.55:6.6.eng: In the same way, a mendicant who practices like this …

an7.55:6.7.eng: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. …’

an7.55:6.8.pli: so pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an7.55:6.8.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished without extra effort.

an7.55:7.1.eng: Take a mendicant who practices like this:

an7.55:7.3.pli: so pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an7.55:7.3.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished with extra effort.

an7.55:7.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, divasaṃsantatte ayokapāle haññamāne papaṭikā nibbattitvā uppatitvā vipule tiṇapuñje vā kaṭṭhapuñje vā nipateyya.
an7.55:7.4.eng: Suppose you struck an iron pot that had been heated all day. Any spark that flew off and floated away would fall on a large heap of grass or twigs.

an7.55:7.5.pli: Sā tattha aggimpi janeyya, dhūmampi janeyya, aggimpi janetvā dhūmampi janetvā tameva vipulaṃ tiṇapuñjaṃ vā kaṭṭhapuñjaṃ vā pariyādiyitvā anāhārā nibbāyeyya.
an7.55:7.5.eng: There it would ignite a fire and produce smoke. But the fire would consume the grass or twigs and become extinguished due to not being fed.

an7.55:7.6.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ paṭipanno hoti:
an7.55:7.6.eng: In the same way, a mendicant who practices like this …

an7.55:7.7.eng: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. …’

an7.55:7.8.pli: so pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an7.55:7.8.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished with extra effort.

an7.55:8.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ paṭipanno hoti:
an7.55:8.1.eng: Take a mendicant who practices like this:

an7.55:8.2.pli: ‘no cassa no ca me siyā, na bhavissati na me bhavissati, yadatthi yaṃ bhūtaṃ taṃ pajahāmī’ti upekkhaṃ paṭilabhati.
an7.55:8.2.eng: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’ They gain equanimity.

an7.55:8.3.pli: So bhave na rajjati, sambhave na rajjati, atthuttari padaṃ santaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
an7.55:8.3.eng: They’re not attached to life, or to creating a new life. And they see with right wisdom that there is a peaceful state beyond.

an7.55:8.4.pli: Tañca khvassa padaṃ na sabbena sabbaṃ sacchikataṃ hoti, tassa na sabbena sabbaṃ mānānusayo pahīno hoti, na sabbena sabbaṃ bhavarāgānusayo pahīno hoti, na sabbena sabbaṃ avijjānusayo pahīno hoti.
an7.55:8.4.eng: But they haven’t totally realized that state. They haven’t completely given up the underlying tendencies of conceit, desire for continued existence, and ignorance.

an7.55:8.5.pli: So pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā uddhaṃsoto hoti akaniṭṭhagāmī.
an7.55:8.5.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they head upstream, going to the Akaniṭṭha realm.

an7.55:8.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, divasaṃsantatte ayokapāle haññamāne papaṭikā nibbattitvā uppatitvā mahante tiṇapuñje vā kaṭṭhapuñje vā nipateyya.
an7.55:8.6.eng: Suppose you struck an iron pot that had been heated all day. Any spark that flew off and floated away would fall on a huge heap of grass or twigs.

an7.55:8.7.pli: Sā tattha aggimpi janeyya, dhūmampi janeyya, aggimpi janetvā dhūmampi janetvā tameva mahantaṃ tiṇapuñjaṃ vā kaṭṭhapuñjaṃ vā pariyādiyitvā gacchampi daheyya, dāyampi daheyya, gacchampi dahitvā dāyampi dahitvā haritantaṃ vā pathantaṃ vā selantaṃ vā udakantaṃ vā ramaṇīyaṃ vā bhūmibhāgaṃ āgamma anāhārā nibbāyeyya.
an7.55:8.7.eng: There it would ignite a fire and produce smoke. And after consuming the grass and twigs, the fire would burn up plants and trees until it reached a green field, a roadside, a cliff’s edge, a body of water, or cleared parkland, where it would be extinguished due to not being fed.

an7.55:8.8.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ paṭipanno hoti:
an7.55:8.8.eng: In the same way, a mendicant who practices like this …

an7.55:8.9.eng: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. …’

an7.55:8.10.pli: so pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā uddhaṃsoto hoti akaniṭṭhagāmī.
an7.55:8.10.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they head upstream, going to the Akaniṭṭha realm.

an7.55:8.11.eng: These are the seven places people are reborn.

an7.55:9.1.eng: And what is complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping?

an7.55:9.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ paṭipanno hoti:
an7.55:9.2.eng: Take a mendicant who practices like this:

an7.55:9.3.pli: ‘no cassa no ca me siyā, na bhavissati na me bhavissati, yadatthi yaṃ bhūtaṃ taṃ pajahāmī’ti upekkhaṃ paṭilabhati.
an7.55:9.3.eng: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’ They gain equanimity.

an7.55:9.4.pli: So bhave na rajjati, sambhave na rajjati, atthuttari padaṃ santaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
an7.55:9.4.eng: They’re not attached to life, or to creating a new life. And they see with right wisdom that there is a peaceful state beyond.

an7.55:9.5.pli: Tañca khvassa padaṃ sabbena sabbaṃ sacchikataṃ hoti, tassa sabbena sabbaṃ mānānusayo pahīno hoti, sabbena sabbaṃ bhavarāgānusayo pahīno hoti, sabbena sabbaṃ avijjānusayo pahīno hoti.
an7.55:9.5.eng: And they have totally realized that state. They’ve completely given up the underlying tendencies of conceit, desire for continued existence, and ignorance.

an7.55:9.6.pli: So āsavānaṃ khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an7.55:9.6.eng: They’ve realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an7.55:9.7.eng: This is called complete extinguishment with no fuel for grasping.

an7.55:9.8.pli: Imā kho, bhikkhave, satta purisagatiyo anupādā ca parinibbānan”ti.
an7.55:9.8.eng: These are the seven places people are reborn, and extinguishment by not grasping.”

an7.56:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
an7.56:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

an7.56:1.3.pli: Atha kho dve devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ gijjhakūṭaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho ekā devatā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an7.56:1.3.eng: Then, late at night, two glorious deities, lighting up the entire Vulture’s Peak, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side. One deity said to him,

an7.56:1.5.eng: The other deity said to him,

an7.56:1.6.eng: “Sir, these nuns are well freed with no residue!”

an7.56:1.7.eng: This is what those deities said,

an7.56:1.9.pli: Atha kho tā devatā “samanuñño satthā”ti bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyiṃsu.
an7.56:1.9.eng: Then those deities, knowing that the teacher approved, bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.

an7.56:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassā rattiyā accayena bhikkhū āmantesi:
an7.56:2.1.eng: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened.

an7.56:2.2.pli: “imaṃ, bhikkhave, rattiṃ dve devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ gijjhakūṭaṃ obhāsetvā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho, bhikkhave, ekā devatā maṃ etadavoca:

an7.56:2.7.pli: Idaṃ vatvā maṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyiṃsū”ti.

an7.56:3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhagavato avidūre nisinno hoti.
an7.56:3.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was sitting not far from the Buddha.

an7.56:3.3.eng: “Which gods know whether a person has anything left over or not?”

an7.56:3.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena tisso nāma bhikkhu adhunākālaṅkato aññataraṃ brahmalokaṃ upapanno hoti.
an7.56:3.5.eng: Now, at that time a monk named Tissa had recently passed away and been reborn in a realm of divinity.

an7.56:3.7.eng: Tissa the Divinity was very mighty and powerful.

an7.56:4.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evamevaṃ—gijjhakūṭe pabbate antarahito tasmiṃ brahmaloke pāturahosi.
an7.56:4.1.eng: And then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from the Vulture’s Peak and reappeared in that realm of divinity.

an7.56:4.2.pli: Addasā kho tisso brahmā āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
an7.56:4.2.eng: Tissa saw Moggallāna coming off in the distance,

an7.56:4.6.pli: Cirassaṃ kho, mārisa moggallāna, imaṃ pariyāyamakāsi, yadidaṃ idhāgamanāya.
an7.56:4.6.eng: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.

an7.56:4.7.eng: Sit, my good Moggallāna, this seat is for you.”

an7.56:4.8.pli: Nisīdi kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno paññatte āsane.
an7.56:4.8.eng: Moggallāna sat down on the seat spread out.

an7.56:4.9.pli: Tissopi kho brahmā āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
an7.56:4.9.eng: Then Tissa bowed to Moggallāna and sat to one side.

an7.56:4.10.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho tissaṃ brahmānaṃ āyasmā mahāmoggallāno etadavoca:

an7.56:4.11.pli: “katamesānaṃ kho, tissa, devānaṃ evaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
an7.56:4.11.eng: “Which gods know whether a person has anything left over or not?”

an7.56:4.13.pli: “Brahmakāyikānaṃ kho, mārisa moggallāna, devānaṃ evaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
an7.56:4.13.eng: “The gods of the Divinity’s host know this.”

an7.56:5.1.pli: “Sabbesaññeva kho, tissa, brahmakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ evaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
an7.56:5.1.eng: “But do all of them know this?”

an7.56:5.3.pli: “Na kho, mārisa moggallāna, sabbesaṃ brahmakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ evaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
an7.56:5.3.eng: “No, my good Moggallāna, not all of them.

an7.56:6.1.pli: Ye kho te, mārisa moggallāna, brahmakāyikā devā brahmena āyunā santuṭṭhā brahmena vaṇṇena brahmena sukhena brahmena yasena brahmena ādhipateyyena santuṭṭhā, te uttari nissaraṇaṃ yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti.
an7.56:6.1.eng: Those gods of the Divinity’s host who are content with the lifespan of the Divinity, with the beauty, happiness, glory, and sovereignty of the Divinity, and who don’t truly understand any escape beyond:

an7.56:6.4.pli: Ye ca kho te, mārisa moggallāna, brahmakāyikā devā brahmena āyunā asantuṭṭhā, brahmena vaṇṇena brahmena sukhena brahmena yasena brahmena ādhipateyyena asantuṭṭhā, te ca uttari nissaraṇaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti.
an7.56:6.4.eng: But those gods of the Divinity’s host who are not content with the lifespan of the Divinity, with the beauty, happiness, glory, and sovereignty of the Divinity, and who do truly understand any escape beyond:

an7.56:7.1.pli: Idha, mārisa moggallāna, bhikkhu ubhatobhāgavimutto hoti.
an7.56:7.1.eng: Take a mendicant who is freed both ways.

an7.56:7.4.pli: Yāvassa kāyo ṭhassati tāva naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā.
an7.56:7.4.eng: As long as their body remains they will be seen by gods and humans.

an7.56:7.5.pli: Kāyassa bhedā na naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā’ti.
an7.56:7.5.eng: But when their body breaks up gods and humans will see them no more.’

an7.56:7.6.pli: Evampi kho, mārisa moggallāna, tesaṃ devānaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
an7.56:7.6.eng: This too is how those gods know whether a person has anything left over or not.

an7.56:8.1.pli: Idha pana, mārisa moggallāna, bhikkhu paññāvimutto hoti.
an7.56:8.1.eng: Take a mendicant who is freed by wisdom.

an7.56:8.4.pli: Yāvassa kāyo ṭhassati tāva naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā.
an7.56:8.4.eng: As long as their body remains they will be seen by gods and humans.

an7.56:8.5.pli: Kāyassa bhedā na naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā’ti.
an7.56:8.5.eng: But when their body breaks up gods and humans will see them no more.’

an7.56:8.6.pli: Evampi kho, mārisa moggallāna, tesaṃ devānaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
an7.56:8.6.eng: This too is how those gods know whether a person has anything left over or not.

an7.56:9.1.pli: Idha pana, mārisa moggallāna, bhikkhu kāyasakkhī hoti.
an7.56:9.1.eng: Take a mendicant who is a direct witness.

an7.56:9.4.pli: Appeva nāma ayamāyasmā anulomikāni senāsanāni paṭisevamāno kalyāṇamitte bhajamāno indriyāni samannānayamāno—
an7.56:9.4.eng: Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties.

an7.56:9.5.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyā’ti.
an7.56:9.5.eng: Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

an7.56:9.6.pli: Evampi kho, mārisa moggallāna, tesaṃ devānaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
an7.56:9.6.eng: This too is how those gods know whether a person has anything left over or not.

an7.56:10.1.pli: Idha pana, mārisa moggallāna, bhikkhu diṭṭhippatto hoti …pe…
an7.56:10.1.eng: Take a mendicant who is attained to view. …

an7.56:10.5.eng: ‘This venerable is a follower of teachings.

an7.56:10.6.pli: Appeva nāma ayamāyasmā anulomikāni senāsanāni paṭisevamāno kalyāṇamitte bhajamāno indriyāni samannānayamāno—
an7.56:10.6.eng: Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties.

an7.56:10.7.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyā’ti.
an7.56:10.7.eng: Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

an7.56:10.8.pli: Evampi kho, mārisa moggallāna, tesaṃ devānaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
an7.56:10.8.eng: This too is how those gods know whether a person has anything left over or not.”

an7.56:11.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno tissassa brahmuno bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evamevaṃ—brahmaloke antarahito gijjhakūṭe pabbate pāturahosi.
an7.56:11.1.eng: Moggallāna approved and agreed with what Tissa the Divinity said. Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared on the Vulture’s Peak.

an7.56:11.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
an7.56:11.2.eng: Then Mahāmoggallāna went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,

an7.56:11.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno yāvatako ahosi tissena brahmunā saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo taṃ sabbaṃ bhagavato ārocesi.
an7.56:11.3.eng: and told him what had happened.

an7.56:12.1.pli: “Na hi pana te, moggallāna, tisso brahmā sattamaṃ animittavihāriṃ puggalaṃ deseti”.
an7.56:12.1.eng: “But Moggallāna, Tissa the Divinity didn’t teach the seventh individual, the signless meditator.”

an7.56:12.2.eng: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!

an7.56:12.3.pli: Yaṃ bhagavā sattamaṃ animittavihāriṃ puggalaṃ deseyya. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
an7.56:12.3.eng: May the Buddha teach the seventh individual, the signless meditator. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

an7.56:12.4.pli: “Tena hi, moggallāna, suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
an7.56:12.4.eng: “Well then, Moggallāna, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an7.56:12.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhagavato paccassosi.

an7.56:13.1.pli: “Idha, moggallāna, bhikkhu sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja viharati.
an7.56:13.1.eng: “Moggallāna, take the case of a mendicant who, not focusing on any signs, enters and remains in the signless immersion of the heart.

an7.56:13.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho āyasmā sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja viharati.
an7.56:13.3.eng: ‘This venerable, not focusing on any signs, enters and remains in the signless immersion of the heart.

an7.56:13.4.pli: Appeva nāma ayamāyasmā anulomikāni senāsanāni paṭisevamāno kalyāṇamitte bhajamāno indriyāni samannānayamāno—
an7.56:13.4.eng: Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties.

an7.56:13.5.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyā’ti.
an7.56:13.5.eng: Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

an7.56:13.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, moggallāna, tesaṃ devānaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
an7.56:13.6.eng: This too is how those gods know whether a person has anything left over or not.”

an7.57:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
an7.57:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

an7.57:1.3.pli: Atha kho sīho senāpati yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho sīho senāpati bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an7.57:1.3.eng: Then General Sīha went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an7.57:1.4.pli: “sakkā nu kho, bhante, sandiṭṭhikaṃ dānaphalaṃ paññāpetun”ti?
an7.57:1.4.eng: “Sir, can you point out a fruit of giving that’s apparent in the present life?”

an7.57:2.1.pli: “Tena hi, sīha, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi, yathā te khameyya tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi.
an7.57:2.1.eng: “Well then, Sīha, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

an7.57:2.4.pli: eko puriso assaddho maccharī kadariyo paribhāsako, eko puriso saddho dānapati anuppadānarato.
an7.57:2.4.eng: One is faithless, stingy, miserly, and abusive. One is a faithful donor who loves charity.

an7.57:2.5.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, sīha, kaṃ nu kho arahanto paṭhamaṃ anukampantā anukampeyyuṃ:
an7.57:2.5.eng: Which do you think the perfected ones will show sympathy for first?”

an7.57:2.6.pli: ‘yo vā so puriso assaddho maccharī kadariyo paribhāsako, yo vā so puriso saddho dānapati anuppadānarato’”ti?

an7.57:3.1.pli: “Yo so, bhante, puriso assaddho maccharī kadariyo paribhāsako, kintaṃ arahanto paṭhamaṃ anukampantā anukampissanti.
an7.57:3.1.eng: “Why would the perfected ones first show sympathy for the person who is faithless, stingy, miserly, and abusive?

an7.57:3.2.pli: Yo ca kho so, bhante, puriso saddho dānapati anuppadānarato taṃyeva arahanto paṭhamaṃ anukampantā anukampeyyuṃ”.
an7.57:3.2.eng: They’d show sympathy first for the faithful donor who loves charity.”

an7.57:4.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, sīha, kaṃ nu kho arahanto paṭhamaṃ upasaṅkamantā upasaṅkameyyuṃ:
an7.57:4.1.eng: “Which do you think the perfected ones will first approach?”

an7.57:4.2.pli: ‘yo vā so puriso assaddho maccharī kadariyo paribhāsako, yo vā so puriso saddho dānapati anuppadānarato’”ti?

an7.57:4.3.pli: “Yo so, bhante, puriso assaddho maccharī kadariyo paribhāsako, kintaṃ arahanto paṭhamaṃ upasaṅkamantā upasaṅkamissanti.

an7.57:4.4.pli: Yo ca kho so, bhante, puriso saddho dānapati anuppadānarato taṃyeva arahanto paṭhamaṃ upasaṅkamantā upasaṅkameyyuṃ”.
an7.57:4.4.eng: “They’d first approach the faithful donor who loves charity.”

an7.57:5.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, sīha, kassa nu kho arahanto paṭhamaṃ paṭiggaṇhantā paṭiggaṇheyyuṃ:
an7.57:5.1.eng: “Which do you think the perfected ones will receive alms from first?”

an7.57:5.2.pli: ‘yo vā so puriso assaddho maccharī kadariyo paribhāsako, yo vā so puriso saddho dānapati anuppadānarato’”ti?

an7.57:5.3.pli: “Yo so, bhante, puriso assaddho maccharī kadariyo paribhāsako, kintaṃ tassa arahanto paṭhamaṃ paṭiggaṇhantā paṭiggaṇhissanti.

an7.57:5.4.pli: Yo ca kho so, bhante, puriso saddho dānapati anuppadānarato tasseva arahanto paṭhamaṃ paṭiggaṇhantā paṭiggaṇheyyuṃ”.
an7.57:5.4.eng: “They’d receive alms first from the faithful donor who loves charity.”

an7.57:6.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, sīha, kassa nu kho arahanto paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ desentā deseyyuṃ:
an7.57:6.1.eng: “Which do you think the perfected ones will teach the Dhamma to first?”

an7.57:6.2.pli: ‘yo vā so puriso assaddho maccharī kadariyo paribhāsako, yo vā so puriso saddho dānapati anuppadānarato’”ti?

an7.57:6.3.pli: “Yo so, bhante, puriso assaddho maccharī kadariyo paribhāsako, kintaṃ tassa arahanto paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ desentā desessanti.

an7.57:6.4.pli: Yo ca kho so, bhante, puriso saddho dānapati anuppadānarato tasseva arahanto paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ desentā deseyyuṃ”.
an7.57:6.4.eng: “They’d first teach the Dhamma to the faithful donor who loves charity.”

an7.57:7.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, sīha, kassa nu kho kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggaccheyya:
an7.57:7.1.eng: “Which do you think would get a good reputation?”

an7.57:7.2.pli: ‘yo vā so puriso assaddho maccharī kadariyo paribhāsako, yo vā so puriso saddho dānapati anuppadānarato’”ti?

an7.57:7.3.pli: “Yo so, bhante, puriso assaddho maccharī kadariyo paribhāsako, kintaṃ tassa kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggacchissati.

an7.57:7.4.pli: Yo ca kho so, bhante, puriso saddho dānapati anuppadānarato tasseva kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggaccheyya”.
an7.57:7.4.eng: “The faithful donor who loves charity would get a good reputation.”

an7.57:8.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, sīha, ko nu kho yaṃyadeva parisaṃ upasaṅkameyya, yadi khattiyaparisaṃ yadi brāhmaṇaparisaṃ yadi gahapatiparisaṃ yadi samaṇaparisaṃ visārado upasaṅkameyya amaṅkubhūto:
an7.57:8.1.eng: “Which do you think would enter any kind of assembly bold and assured, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics?”

an7.57:8.2.pli: ‘yo vā so puriso assaddho maccharī kadariyo paribhāsako, yo vā so puriso saddho dānapati anuppadānarato’”ti?

an7.57:8.3.pli: “Yo so, bhante, puriso assaddho maccharī kadariyo paribhāsako, kiṃ so yaṃyadeva parisaṃ upasaṅkamissati, yadi khattiyaparisaṃ yadi brāhmaṇaparisaṃ yadi gahapatiparisaṃ yadi samaṇaparisaṃ visārado upasaṅkamissati amaṅkubhūto.
an7.57:8.3.eng: “How could the person who is faithless, stingy, miserly, and abusive enter any kind of assembly bold and assured, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics?

an7.57:8.4.pli: Yo ca kho so, bhante, puriso saddho dānapati anuppadānarato so yaṃyadeva parisaṃ upasaṅkameyya, yadi khattiyaparisaṃ yadi brāhmaṇaparisaṃ yadi gahapatiparisaṃ yadi samaṇaparisaṃ visārado upasaṅkameyya amaṅkubhūto”.
an7.57:8.4.eng: The faithful donor who loves charity would enter any kind of assembly bold and assured, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.”

an7.57:9.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, sīha, ko nu kho kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyya:
an7.57:9.1.eng: “When their body breaks up, after death, which do you think would be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm?”

an7.57:9.2.pli: ‘yo vā so puriso assaddho maccharī kadariyo paribhāsako, yo vā so puriso saddho dānapati anuppadānarato’”ti?

an7.57:9.3.pli: “Yo so, bhante, puriso assaddho maccharī kadariyo paribhāsako, kiṃ so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjissati.
an7.57:9.3.eng: “Why would the person who is faithless, stingy, miserly, and abusive be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm?

an7.57:9.4.pli: Yo ca kho so, bhante, puriso saddho dānapati anuppadānarato so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjeyya.
an7.57:9.4.eng: The faithful donor who loves charity would, when their body breaks up, after death, be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an7.57:10.1.pli: Yānimāni, bhante, bhagavatā sandiṭṭhikāni dānaphalāni akkhātāni, nāhaṃ ettha bhagavato saddhāya gacchāmi.
an7.57:10.1.eng: When it comes to these fruits of giving that are apparent in the present life, I don’t have to rely on faith in the Buddha,

an7.57:10.3.pli: Ahaṃ, bhante, dāyako dānapati, maṃ arahanto paṭhamaṃ anukampantā anukampanti.
an7.57:10.3.eng: I’m a giver, a donor, and the perfected ones show sympathy for me first.

an7.57:10.4.pli: Ahaṃ, bhante, dāyako dānapati, maṃ arahanto paṭhamaṃ upasaṅkamantā upasaṅkamanti.
an7.57:10.4.eng: I’m a giver, and the perfected ones approach me first.

an7.57:10.5.pli: Ahaṃ, bhante, dāyako dānapati, mayhaṃ arahanto paṭhamaṃ paṭiggaṇhantā paṭiggaṇhanti.
an7.57:10.5.eng: I’m a giver, and the perfected ones receive alms from me first.

an7.57:10.6.pli: Ahaṃ, bhante, dāyako dānapati, mayhaṃ arahanto paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ desentā desenti.
an7.57:10.6.eng: I’m a giver, and the perfected ones teach me Dhamma first.

an7.57:10.7.pli: Ahaṃ, bhante, dāyako dānapati, mayhaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
an7.57:10.7.eng: I’m a giver, and I have this good reputation:

an7.57:10.8.eng: ‘General Sīha gives, serves, and attends on the Saṅgha.’

an7.57:10.9.pli: Ahaṃ, bhante, dāyako dānapati yaṃyadeva parisaṃ upasaṅkamāmi, yadi khattiyaparisaṃ …pe… yadi samaṇaparisaṃ visārado upasaṅkamāmi amaṅkubhūto.
an7.57:10.9.eng: I’m a giver, I enter any kind of assembly bold and assured, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.

an7.57:10.10.pli: Yānimāni, bhante, bhagavatā sandiṭṭhikāni dānaphalāni akkhātāni, nāhaṃ ettha bhagavato saddhāya gacchāmi.
an7.57:10.10.eng: When it comes to these fruits of giving that are apparent in the present life, I don’t have to rely on faith in the Buddha,

an7.57:10.12.pli: Yañca kho maṃ, bhante, bhagavā evamāha:

an7.57:10.13.pli: ‘dāyako, sīha, dānapati kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjatī’ti.
an7.57:10.13.eng: ‘When a giver’s body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ I don’t know this,

an7.57:10.14.pli: Etāhaṃ na jānāmi, ettha ca panāhaṃ, bhagavato saddhāya gacchāmī”ti.
an7.57:10.14.eng: so I have to rely on faith in the Buddha.”

an7.57:10.15.eng: “That’s so true, Sīha! That’s so true!

an7.57:10.16.pli: Dāyako, sīha, dānapati kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjatī”ti.
an7.57:10.16.eng: When a giver’s body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”
